title: Cole Green Way Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Robert Edwards / One of the entrance/exit points to the Cole Green Way, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: One of the entrance-exit points to the Cole Green Way

images.title: Stephen Craven / Cole Green picnic area, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cole Green picnic area. Part of the former station site, the picnic site is shown on O.S. maps but the dense tree cover makes it invisible on aerial mapping.

images.title: Stephen Dawson / Remains of Cole Green station, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Remains of Cole Green station.

images.title: Stephen Craven / Cole Green picnic area
images.caption: Cole Green picnic area. Part of the former station site

images.title: Nigel Cox / Cole Green: The Well
images.caption: Cole Green. This area is located just north of the route and includes this attractive green. The stone structure is the former village well, now sealed up but with the remains of the metal pulley wheel and support still in place.

images.title: The Cowper Arms on Station Road, Cole Green by David Howard, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Cowper Arms on Station Road, Cole Green

images.title: Nigel Cox / Hertingfordbury: St Mary's Lane railway bridge
images.caption: Hertingfordbury, St Mary's Lane railway bridge. The long since dismantled Welwyn to Hertford railway crossed St Mary's Lane by means of this simple but rather graceful bridge. The clearance is 11' 3".

images.title: Jim Osley / Hertford Viaduct
images.caption: Hertford Viaduct carries the Hertford Loop Line over the River Mimram, a tributary of the River Lea, between Hertford and Hertingfordbury in the county of Hertfordshire, England. This structure is located near the eastern end of the route.

description: Travel from Welwyn Garden City to Hertford along a disused railway line on this easy cycle or walk in Hertfordshire. The route follows National Cycle Network Route 61 on a flat, traffic free path. There's nice tree lined sections and views of the surrounding open countryside. The route starts on the outskirts of Welwyn Garden City and runs through Letty Green before finishing at Hertford. The route links with the Ayot Greenway at Welwyn Garden City. It's a similar rail trail which runs to Wheathampstead along National Cycle Route 57. The Alban Way also runs from nearby Hatfield to St Albans. Walkers can pick up the Lea Valley Walk and enjoy a riverside stroll. See the St Albans Cycle Routes page for more rides around the area. See the National Cycle Route 61 page for details of the full route which runs from Maidenhead to Hoddesdon.
